body:
Can you run the find command again with `--debug-fuse` which will create even more output and post the result please?  Attach it to this issue would be ideal, or email it to me nick@craig-wood.com with a link to this issue in if it has confidential stuff in.

Are there any versions of rclone which do work OK?

How you are mounting it? Just running it from the command line and leaving it in the foreground / systemd service / some other method?

The input / output error usually is around the process being killed/dying/disappearing and fuse doesn't think it has been unmounted so the fuse part remains as something is accessing the mount point.

Are you able to share the whole debug log?

> Are there any versions of rclone which do work OK?

No

> How you are mounting it? Just running it from the command line and leaving it in the foreground / systemd service / some other method?

I start it on the command line in foreground. It does not die.

> Are you able to share the whole debug log?

Sadly no (does contain PII of not just me but colleagues). I will continue to try narrow down how to reproduce a minimal log. I did try to `strace find` to see which call exactly does produce the error but no luck so far.

So you are getting an input/output error and the process is still there? 

What OS / kernel?

```
felix@gemini:~$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID:	Debian
Description:	Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)
Release:	10
Codename:	buster
felix@gemini:~$ uname -a
Linux gemini 4.19.0-6-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.19.67-2+deb10u2 (2019-11-11) x86_64 GNU/Linux
felix@gemini:~$
```

> What OS / kernel?

```
$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	:core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch
Distributor ID:	Fedora
Description:	Fedora release 31 (Thirty One)
Release:	31
Codename:	ThirtyOne
```

Can you share the kernel as well? 

```
uname -a
```

> So you are getting an input/output error and the process is still there?

Yes. I also made sure that the log:

```
2020/01/16 19:49:30 DEBUG : /: ReadDirAll: 
2020/01/16 19:49:30 DEBUG : /: >ReadDirAll: item=1556, err=<nil>
```

is exactly what happened during the `find` (with the data cached), nothing else. I do have ~ 1.5k files in the folder. I am now moving some away and see if it still happens.

> Kernel

```
$ uname -a
Linux knight1 5.3.16-300.fc31.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Dec 13 17:59:04 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

I did on a test VM but the kernel version is ahead of yours.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5088712/72644682-9a241400-393f-11ea-8309-7cec930fc19b.png)

I'm also not using the beta version but the latest stable. Are you using the beta for a particular fix? Does the same issue happen on 1.50.2?

I tried the beta because of this issue. I tested two stable releases first though.

I had 1.5k files in the root of my drive (and then more in folders). I moved all files that where directly in the root folder to a new directory and left all the others folders as they where. Now I get the error if I list the files in that new folder. Narrowed it down somewhat ;) so it is not related to folders/subfolders.

Can you run with `--debug-fuse` and just examine the logs for the second (cached) run?

It must be some interaction with fuse that isn't touching rclone.  Maybe there is a file with an incorrect name (eg contains a `/` or is `.` or `..`) that the kernel doesn't like.

You should see the error which will look something like `error=EIO` hopefully.

If you can post the bits before that (redact as necessary) that should help!
After some more bisecting: I have a file name of 1040 characters. It causes the error.

rename.from: input/output error on google drive mount
rename.to: input/output error on google drive mount with filename longer than 1024 chars

body:
How to reproduce:
```

```

Would produce the error (1025 chars). Removing the `b` at the end, gets it back down to 1024 and it works again.

Well done for working the problem out :-)

I think we had a similar problem before - see 59026c4761e3926f6a54b6518472c54345e0b7fc with length 4k.  I wonder if FUSE has changed since then.

I can change the threshold to 1k so these files get skipped easily enough

I've done this here

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.50.2-171-g1f071956-fix-3884-long-name-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

Can you have a go?

I'm not 100% happy with just dropping the files (with an ERROR message) though.

I've got a patch pending to fix this - but I'd like to hear from you @FlorianLudwig to see if it fixes your problem or not. Can you have a test of the above beta code?

Thanks

Hmm. I can't seem to replicate it as all my file systems are not letting me make a file that long as I just get file too long.

@FlorianLudwig  - are you able to give a test so we can confirm it works?

@animosity22 @ncw To reproduce the problem:

1. create an empty document on google drive
2. name it: ""
3. mount drive with rclone
4. `ls`

Without the patch just "I/O error" appears. With the patch:

```
2020/05/21 16:20:13 ERROR : /: Name too long (1034 bytes) for FUSE, skipping: .odt
```

I am happy with that. Mapping filenames might lead to other problems... At least now it's clear what's wrong, thanks!
